What happens to a pawned firearm when the background check comes back with a non-approval from state and the FBI/NCIC? All subsequent appeals denied.
 
 Does this weapon automatically become the property of the pawn shop proprietor to re-sell or whatever? Is the person that pawned the item SOL?
 
 Thanks for any info.
 
 Giseuda

SOL is "XXXX out of luck".
 
 The pawn shop is required to do a background check... by LAW!! As if you went to a gun store an attempted to buy a gun. Same exact rules.
 
 Am I entitled to any compensation for my property? I pawned this gun thinking I would have no problem getting it back. SURPRISE!!
 
 I'm still trying to find out what I did that would cause this problem. Getting any information is another bureaucratic nightmare. Nobody will tell you anything. I'm now being asked to be re-fingerprinted, buy a money order for $18.00, and submit another request to the FBI/NCIC in Clarksburg, W. Virginia. This is just to find out what they are holding against me.
 
 
 Giseuda

According to this source, you might have trouble passing a background check if you have the same name as a convicted felon or a similiar address or social security number. 
 
 http://www.packing.org/news/article.jsp/2899/

Tim,
 
 Thanks, that was an interesting thread.
 
 I too, have had fingerprints taken in the military for security clearance, and on various other occasions in my life. I'm 52 years old. I was not an angel but never a criminal.
 
 The difference in my situation is that I 've been turned down after an appeal. The FBI/NCIC has my name and fingerprints tied to a crime. Ridiculous as it may sound, I don't have any clue as to what it was. I'm doing my damndest to find out now.
 
 My advice: Never, ever, pawn a firearm. Believe me, it ain't worth it.
 
 Giseuda
